item.title: The Super Mario Galaxy Movie Is Officially Announced For Spring 2026, Heading Into Space
item.content:encoded:
As rumored yesterday, the sequel to 2023’s The Super Mario Bros. Movie from Nintendo and Illumination has been announced by Nintendo during the September Nintendo Direct. Featuring all the original actors from the previous movie, The Super Mario Galaxy Movie is set to release in spring 2026, picking up on the theme of the 2007 Super Mario Galaxy Wii game. The footage shown so far is brief, oddly not showing anything of Mario and chums actually in space, but rather just a very pretty view of rolling green hills in the Mushroom Kingdom. But there will be months of trailers to come.

Nintendo confirmed the entire original cast is back for the sequel, and yes, that means Chris Pratt is once more going to give us his generic performance as Mario. Sigh. But it also means the glorious return of Jack Black as Bowser, along with Anya Taylor-Joy as Peach, Charlie Day as Luigi, and Keegan-Michael Key as Toad.

There’s still no signs of life at the registered supermariogalaxy.movie URL, which is how people were tipped off to the movie’s title yesterday. That means there’s also no more information than Miyamoto’s declaration that the characters will be visiting space for the film, presumably across a series of teeny-tiny planets to match the nature of the classic games. It should offer a chance for a huge array of silly escapades, and ideally Mario dressing up as a bee. Because that is the cutest thing that has ever happened.

You can find the brief footage of the new movie right here:

item.title: Beelink’s Ryzen 7 Mini PC Falls Below Prime Day Pricing, A Tempting Windows Alternative for Mac Mini Users
item.content:encoded:
The mini PC wave doesn’t seem to be cresting anytime soon. Far from it, in fact, as more and more new models hit the market — and, like this Windows 11 Pro model from Beelink — hit the Amazon sale list. The Beelink SER5 PRO Mini PC has an AMD Ryzen 7 processor that can reach speeds of up to 4.5GHz, and three-monitor support via HDMI, DisplayPort, and USB-C, all of which can support 4K resolution.

This mini PC has all the connections you need, including Wi-Fi 6 and Bluetooth 5.2, and during this limited-time Amazon deal, this price is very definitely right — just $265 after a 26% drop from its usual retail price of $360. There’s a whole lot of productivity and computing muscle in this small package that’s now at a smaller price, so read on and decide.

See at Amazon

Is This You?

A mini PC is not going to be your hardcore gaming rig or your high-end 3D-editing station. But if you’re looking for a PC that’s reliable, more than fast enough for everyday productivity tasks and streaming, quick for browsing, and positioned in an excellent price point, that’s a pretty solid description of the Beelink SER5 PRO. If you value efficient spatial organization and hate the idea of adding a bulky tower or even a large laptop to your desk, then the SER5 PRO is really for you.

The SER5 PRO is so small that you can easily fit three 4K monitors on your desk. And you’ll be able to run them all at the same time, since the SER5 PRO’s Ryzen 7 5825U 8-core processor, 16GB of RAM (expandable to 64GB), and 2000MHz AMD Radeon Graphics 8 chip provide more than enough graphic-generating muscle. There’s an HDMI 60Hz port, DisplayPort, and USB-C port at the ready for your monitors, along with four USB-A 3.2 Gen2 ports and a 2.5Gbps LAN for super-fast hardwired internet.

Built to Last

The Beelink SER5 PRO is designed to be your everyday PC for a long time to come, and that’s not just because of the sturdy construction bolstered by a silent high-speed fan, heat sink, and other safety features to guard against overheating. It’s also expandable — there are dual SO-DIMM RAM slots so you can easily boost the RAM as high as 64GB, and the 500GB SSD storage can be swapped out for one as large as 4TB.

The mini PCs are only going to keep becoming more common and more advanced, but this Beelink SER5 PRO has the power to be your everyday desktop PC right now, and also the capacity to expand to meet future workloads. The Amazon limited-time deal price of $265 may end up being your PC budget for years to come.

item.title: Slay The Spire 2 Is Now A 2026 Release, But Don’t Blame Hornet
item.content:encoded:
When it comes to deckbuilding roguelites, there’s one name that tops almost every list: Slay the Spire. The incredible 2019 release from Mega Crit is still enormously popular, but six years on we’re definitely ready for its sequel. Sadly, that’s now looking like it’ll be a seven year wait, with the game’s Early Access launch delayed until next March. And no, it has nothing to do with the release of Hollow Knight: Silksong.

Originally slated to appear this fall, Slay the Spire 2 is set 1,000 years after the massive hit original, offering a more complicated path through the Spire, new characters joining the old crew, and as-yet unrevealed “new ways to play” (although the update does reveal one!). And given that the original game, six years later, still routinely sees 18-20,000 people playing every day on Steam (let alone on console and mobile), you can only imagine how many people are waiting in digital lines to be able to start playing the follow-up.

“After a lot of internal discussion,” a very lengthy update post for the game begins, “we’ve made the call to move Slay the Spire 2‘s Early Access launch to a secret Thursday in March 2026.”

“There’s no single dramatic reason,” the post continues. “Some personal life stuff hit the team (everyone’s okay!), we kept saying ‘wouldn’t it be cool if…’ one too many times, and honestly, the game just needs more polish to meet our standards.” Thus another six months development before the game reaches players.

Knowing exactly where people’s minds would immediately go, an FAQ about the delay begins with the question, “Is the real reason for the delay the timing of the Silksong release?” But, Mega Crit insists, this had nothing to do with it.

“We got together as a team to determine our new release window before Silksong’s date was announced. The timing just worked out like that, but on the bright side, everyone can keep busy playing Silksong during the wait!”

The FAQ continues with an even more conspiratorial theory: that the developers are spending too much time on merch and community events. (You have to assume this is something on a forum or Discord somewhere, right?) Again, they say no.

“Our merch is made by 3rd party partners and our community manager is the primary liaison on our team for collabs like that. No game development was harmed in the making of those plushies! Likewise, anything community-focused that we create, participate in, or promote is generally handled by the CM and doesn’t cut into any game development time.”

Mega Crit also promise no radio silence between now and March. But then the post goes on to reveal a brand new Slay the Spire 2 feature: “alternate acts.”

Once unlocked, upon entering a new act in Slay the Spire 2, you will be randomly greeted with one of two possible acts. These acts differ radically in their environments, enemies, events, and bosses, all of which greatly increase the variety of gameplay between runs. For instance, Act 1a is Overgrowth, a lush, tangled ruin with much of its fauna resembling mystical woodland creatures and sentient flora that might just eat you alive. This is the act you’ve primarily been seeing in our teasers and trailers, though there’s still plenty left to uncover here. Act 1b is known as the Underdocks, a miry waterway connected to the Spire’s sewer system, from which all manner of mutant sea creatures and vagrants might emerge. We’ve only just begun to tease the trove of content that lurks within these murky depths.

As the mathematically-inclined among you have probably realized, that means there will be double the amount of content in this new act structure. We won’t be launching with all of the alternate acts right away, but Acts 2b and 3b will come later down the road in Early Access updates. The capabilities of these different enemies, the opportunities these events offer, and how they all might impact your strategy as you ascend the Spire will be seen in time.

The rest of the post features some superb community engagement (really, developers need to study this for a class in how to connect with customers), including player art, in-jokes, and even a Connections wall. It’s lovely stuff, which goes some way to easing the blow of another six months to wait.

item.title: This HP USB-C Dock 11-in-1 Adapter Keeps Dropping in Price, Now a Clearance-Level 55% Off Deal
item.content:encoded:
See all those wires cluttering your desktop? Quick — do you know right away where all of them go, and which ones are powering or connecting what device? It sucks when the cable octopus turns into a vicious cable kraken and kills any semblance of organization on your desk, but Amazon’s running a fat deal on the ultimate clutter-killing hub: HP’s G5 11-in-1 dock works with any USB-C or Thunderbolt-enabled laptop or PC, and it’s never been priced lower than it is right now at just $104.

When the opportunity presents itself to give your work or gaming setup the ultimate dose of organization and power management while saving a huge 55% off the regular price of $230, you jump at it. We don’t make up the rules here, we just advise you not to break them.

See at Amazon

Here’s the Lineup

Take another look at your current setup and then read this list of available ports on the HP G5 dock. See how many of your cables will fit in this one unified power hub:

  • 2 DisplayPort 1.4
  • 1 HDMI port
  • 4 USB-A ports (one SuperSpeed)
  • 1 RJ-45 Gig Ethernet
  • 2 USB-C ports (one for data/power out, one to connect to your computer)
  • 1 audio jack

If your desktop or laptop is either USB-C or Thunderbolt compatible (and virtually all of them are now), the HP G5 dock will work with your machine, and work brilliantly. For charging purposes, it brings up to 100W of power to your connected devices. If you’re on a PC, your machine will still get updates pushed through the G5 dock, even if the computer is in sleep mode.

As for the G5 dock itself, it’s an unassuming little device despite that huge number of ports and docks. It’s just 5-by-5 inches square, and stands less than 2 inches tall, so you can tuck it away and effectively hide the source of all of your peripheral connections.

Universal Appeal

The HP name might make you think the G5 dock is a PC-exclusive device, but it works equally well with Macs — anything with a Thunderbolt or USB-C port, across platforms, across desktops and laptops. Anything with the prerequisite hookup can not only be given a dose of cable-management sanity, it can also become a triple-monitor productivity hive.

We’ve seen Amazon run deals on the HP G5 11-in-1 Dock before, and it’s been a solid recommendation every time it comes up. But now that it’s being offered at its lowest price ever — just $104 after a huge 55% price cut — we can’t recommend it more strongly than now.
